I'm not Homophobic; I'm Chick-O-Centric
 By Doug Giles
 Saturday, February 24, 2007
 
 I think I speak for most heterosexual males when I say I'm not homophobic but chick-o-centric. Let's keep it positive, okay? It's not that we dislike you, the gay guy; it's just that we really like girls. It seems no matter how long we compliantly spend in rehab undergoing the most stringent psychotherapy to rid ourselves of our knee-jerk to your mate choice, the simple fact is . . . heterosexual guys don't "get" gays. Period. 
 
 Heck, we don't understand women. What makes you think we'll ever understand a man who doesn't like women yet wants to be a woman? You just rifled right over our heads. In addition, not only are most men incapable of comprehending what a man sees in another man, we also don't care to try to because football is on-so can we all just shut the hell up with the gay stuff and watch the game?!? 
 
 "American Idol" host Ryan Seacrest arrives at the 49th Annual Grammy Awards in Los Angeles February 11, 2007. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni (UNITED STATES) Please, rehab freaks, you're wasting your time on the heterosexual tribe trying to get us to be cool with that which is incomprehensible to us. Just like the homosexual, we are quite happy with our sexual bent and our own little world, so leave us alone, por favor. 
 
 Now, this doesn't mean that heterosexuals hate you, the homosexual. It simply means we're focused on women; which, by command, causes our paths of camaraderie to part. No, this is not a phobia and it doesn't mean we loathe you. It's simply the funk of nature. As a matter of fact, I have several friends that are gay. I kind of view them like dolphins; they're fun, entertaining and creative. I truly enjoy their presence. I just don't know what they get out of eating mullet. My homosexual acquaintances view me in a similar light. 
 
 In the spirit of continuing diplomatic relations with homosexuals, you the gay person, has got to help me out a little bit. If girls are so icky and men are so mondo-jovial, why do you and a lot of your reps take on feminine mannerisms and dress? I would think that if you are going to be gay you would at least be a man about it. 
 
 It's the same thing with many lesbians. I don't get you. When I hear you speak, it's always "men suck, men are beasts, women rule," yet some of you "ladies" dress and act like men. You wear men's Dockers, men's Polos, you've got a short, man's hair cut, you're looking like Joe Pesci with breasts. You're an ugly version of us. I'm just thinking out loud here. What's-the-dillio? Please explain. It seems as if you would embrace femininity in all its glory like Carrot Top does red hair coloring. Where am I going wrong? 
 
 Now, let me help you, the gay constituency, to understand us girl lovers a tad. Most Chick-O-Centric males would not raise an unwaxed eye brow at a homosexual man if he would not shove his gayness in our faces. It's the flamers that freak out most heterosexuals. Case in point: Bobby Trendy and Jay Alexander. They seem like nice guys, but the pink hair, lip gloss, heavy eye liner, constant limp wrist and lisp is overkill. Why not, instead of emulating a TBN host, you follow Rob Halford's lead? That would make it much easier for us to have a beer with you. C'mon . . . work with us, we're trying to get along. 
 
 Here are 10 more things you should know about most typical heterosexual males: 
 
 1. Just because we like art and fine furniture, wash our cars, regularly bathe and brush our teeth, and like nice clothes doesn't mean we're latent. What it means is that your team doesn't have a monopoly on taste or decorum. 
 
 2. No, we don't want highlights in our hair or a manicure/pedicure. 
 
 3. We think Vespas are for beautiful girls to ride. Not guys. Harley's, custom West Coast Choppers, Triumphs, Indians or Von Dutchs = a dude's bike. 
 
 4. We don't like dogs that have "toy" as a prefix to their name. 
 
 5. A hunted wild animal's gut pile is a glorious and beautiful thing. Long live the hunt and the hunter. 
 
 6. Keep your lip gloss; we'll use our Carmex. 
 
 7. We like boots not flip flops. 
 
 
 
 "American Idol" host Ryan Seacrest arrives at the 49th Annual Grammy Awards in Los Angeles February 11, 2007. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni (UNITED STATES) 8. Normal men do not like Celine Dion. If you see us crying during one of her shows, it's not because she struck a nerve with a ballad; but rather we are lamenting our manhood slowly draining away from us as we sit here, for the eight time, and listen to this chick whine. 
 
 9. When we look at a pretty girl, we think "wow" and say, "howdy." To us, the lovely lady lumps trump a man's hairy back any day. Call us crazy. 
 
 10. We don't think Adam and Steve is an improvement or alternative to Adam and Eve. But that's just us. 
 
 The above 411 doesn't mean we be hatin'. 
 
 Now, lastly, for those of you heterosexuals that are in competitive sports and don't like to shower with gays, that's cool. It's your right to scrub your butt with whomever you choose. You gay guys should understand our reluctance and not make a big deal over it. I confess, I'm uncomfortable with showering with a homosexual, unless of course it was Portia de Rossi, and I wasn't married. 
 
 To remedy this situation, I propose the following: how about two shower facilities: one for the heterosexuals demarked by a gigantic poster of Beyonce's Sport's Illustrated Swimsuit cover and one for the homosexuals with a big honking 48 x 60" framed print of Ryan Seacrest wearing a chartreuse colored Speedo. There now ... is everybody happy? 
 
 http://townhall.com/columnists/DougGiles/2007/02/24/i%E2%80%99m_not_homophobic;_i%E2%80%99m_chick-o-centric
After reading this satirical article, I couldn't help but think "Whatta meat-head!" emoticon_rolleyes

Who is this guy? Was this for real, or is it supposed to be some sort of sarcastic attack on homophobic straight men? I mean, come on! "I'm not a homophobe, but gays want to be women, they use lip gloss, and don't have real dogs"? I think he missed lisping, but hit pretty much every other stereotype out there. He may not be "hatin", in that he isn't about to take a baseball bat to anyone, but he clearly has no respect for gays, or any desire to know anything real about them. Clearly whatever "stringent psychotherapy" he's been exposed to didn't take. :)

Wow, I think you are taking that just a bit too seriously. I mean, come on ... do you two actually think any article with "chick-o-centric" in the title is meant to be some serious earth-shattering statement? If people are going to find THAT bit of writing dis-"respect"ful and take it that seriously, then the homosexuality debate is truly doomed.

Wow, I think you are taking that just a bit too seriously. I mean, come on ... do you two actually think any article with "chick-o-centric" in the title is meant to be some serious earth-shattering statement? If people are going to find THAT bit of writing dis-"respect"ful and take it that seriously, then the homosexuality debate is truly doomed.

 
 I think you may be taking our objections a bit too seriously. What he said was stupid and homophobic, sure. But I have no idea who this guy is or how big an audience, if any, he has. If I thought he had the country's ear, if he was running for office, if he set policy; then I'd be concerned. As it is, I'm quite content to just point out what an idiot he seems to be. 
 
 And I'm curious. You don't actually think that anyone who supports gay rights in any way could find that piece anything but disrespectful, do you? Granted, he may not be worth worrying about, but he clearly has no respect for gays at all.

And I'm curious. You don't actually think that anyone who supports gay rights in any way could find that piece anything but disrespectful, do you? Granted, he may not be worth worrying about, but he clearly has no respect for gays at all.

 
 What do you find disrespectful about it?
 
 Maybe it is "disrespectful" but I sometimes that's not necessarily so bad. I don't think it rises to the level of being offensive.

And I'm curious. You don't actually think that anyone who supports gay rights in any way could find that piece anything but disrespectful, do you? Granted, he may not be worth worrying about, but he clearly has no respect for gays at all.

 
 Exactly what do you find disrespectful about it?
 
 Maybe it is "disrespectful" in some ways but I think sometimes that's not necessarily so bad, particularly when something is written tongue-in-cheek as this may be. I don't think it rises to the level of being offensive. It's just an obviously silly article, probably not meant to be taken too seriously.

Exactly what do you find disrespectful about it?
 
 Maybe it is "disrespectful" in some ways but I think sometimes that's not necessarily so bad, particularly when something is written tongue-in-cheek as this may be. I don't think it rises to the level of being offensive. It's just an obviously silly article, probably not meant to be taken too seriously.

 
 If someone insults you, and then follows it up with "just kidding", it's still insulting. The fact that he's being homophobic in a silly manner doesn't make it not homophobic. Unless, of course, it was meant to be satire. In that case, he's simply a poor writer.
 
 As for what was disrespectful, I'll tell you. But don't then turn around and ask what the big deal is. I'm not making a big deal, I'm just answering your question. 
 
 Largely, it's his pandering to stereotypes. For example, "why do you and a lot of your reps take on feminine mannerisms and dress", "Keep your lip gloss", "We like boots not flip flops". Gay doesn't mean feminine. And for the lesbians in the crowd, we have "it's always "men suck, men are beasts, women rule," yet some of you "ladies" dress and act like men." Again, old tired stereotypes. We need to move beyond these ideas, not use them as the basis for "explaining" why straights have problems with gays. Anytime you base an argument on stereoptypes you're basically saying that you don't care enough about your subject to learn even the most basic facts, or in this case possibly that you think that the stereotypes that have followed people for years are funny. Either way, disrespectful.

I think you may be taking our objections a bit too seriously. What he said was stupid and homophobic, sure. But I have no idea who this guy is or how big an audience, if any, he has. If I thought he had the country's ear, if he was running for office, if he set policy; then I'd be concerned. As it is, I'm quite content to just point out what an idiot he seems to be. 
 
 And I'm curious. You don't actually think that anyone who supports gay rights in any way could find that piece anything but disrespectful, do you? Granted, he may not be worth worrying about, but he clearly has no respect for gays at all.

 
 The power of humor to open doors is often underestimated and overlooked. While you may disagree with what was said and how it was said I know that somewhere at least one person had the longest non spiteful period in their life as relates to homosexuals (sad isn't it). 
 
 Liberals often tell conservatives to "lighten up" or "relax", the conservative response often is centered around the need for constant diligence, as if thier very existance is under attack. One' s perception being one's reality means right, wrong or in between it's real. Humor softens that hardness that is so difficult to breakdown in discussing emotional topics like this. 
 
 We are far more accepting of those things that do not threaten us physically, emotionally or intellectually. I have often referred to hetero males, myself included, as needing understanding and added patience, after all we are just big hairy animals. 
 
 Yes some will somehow twist this into more blah blah blah gay bashing, but I am betting a crack just appeared for a couple can either be worked open or slammed shut. Which would you prefer?

Exactly what do you find disrespectful about it?
 
 Maybe it is "disrespectful" in some ways but I think sometimes that's not necessarily so bad, particularly when something is written tongue-in-cheek as this may be. I don't think it rises to the level of being offensive. It's just an obviously silly article, probably not meant to be taken too seriously.

 
 WHOA Im in the gay rights forum siding with jyoshu against Kronus. My gay friends are going to revoke my honorary membership

So if I don't care for football or gut piles I'm gay or "latent"? Somebody ought to remind bonehead that he's safe in the shower.
 
 No one man has the right to define manhood for all men.
Well, insulting is sometimes just part of tongue-in-cheek writing. Personally, I think I'd have a hard time finding any article about being "chick-o-centric" serious enough to be offended.

Personally, I think I'd have a hard time finding any article about being "chick-o-centric" serious enough to be offended.

 
 Ok, so noted.

Here's a Wikipedia entry on this guy ...
 
 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doug_Giles
 
 I couldn't help but laugh at his book title "Raising Boys Feminists Will Hate". Sounds interesting to say the least.

http://www.chalcedon.edu/articles/0503/050301-3duigon.php
 
 http://blogs.salon.com/0003494/stories/2004/10/31/gilesDoug.html
 
 http://mediamatters.org/items/200604250009
 
 Real piece of work.

 
 Yikes - sounds like a whole-sale jack-XXX. And insecure whack who plays uber macho with a Bible. Hell - I am straight woman and already find him tedious. Makes me think of one those guys in the bar, showing off his chest hair and bragging a tale of lies to be impressive. YAAAWWWNNNNN.

Ok, now I have a problem with the guy. He is clearly just trying to dress up homophobia in an "amusing" package to make it more palatable to the masses. By taking on a jocular tone he was probably hoping that people wouldn't take him too seriously, thus letting him push his stereotypes without being labeled, correctly, as a "hater".

Wow, I think you are taking that just a bit too seriously. I mean, come on ... do you two actually think any article with "chick-o-centric" in the title is meant to be some serious earth-shattering statement? If people are going to find THAT bit of writing dis-"respect"ful and take it that seriously, then the homosexuality debate is truly doomed.

 
 Jyoshu, try to get some perspective.
 If somebody wrote an article employing numerous black stereo-types, writing about eating fried chicken and watermelons and Colt 45's, can you understand how blacks might have a reaction to that?
 
 I took it as satire, but at the same time was annoyed at it being posted for readers, where some of them probably actually think this way...
 
 Also, while I do see it as satire, it just wasn't funny.
 Quite frankly, I didn't see any humor in the fact that he talked about not needing or wanting to understand gays, but then he used gay stereo-type after gay stereo-type. I don't see any humor in it because I bump into those types of people all the time. Also while I see an irony in that, I really don't know if the author appreciated the irony of his statements. If the irony of that was part of his point, I really didn't see any sign of him attempting to purposely convey it.
 
 In comedy, if a comedian were to try and bring up those stereo-types, he/she would be typically making fun of the IDEA of the stereo-types. Making fun of the belief in them.
 But I see none of that in this guy's writing. It seems he makes light of "chick-centric", making one comment regarding heterosexuals that I don't think most people take seriously, and then he utilizes a whole LAUNDRY LIST of gay stereo-types, that quite a few people DO believe in.

Jyoshu, try to get some perspective.
 If somebody wrote an article employing numerous black stereo-types, writing about eating fried chicken and watermelons and Colt 45's, can you understand how blacks might have a reaction to that?

 
 Do you really think most of the stereotypes he's using were that serious??? I mean it's not like he was throwing around the promiscuous-thing or the HIV thing or something. I've heard white comedians that made a stereotypical remark about blacks and it was fine--blacks laughing too. We aren't talking about a "Michael Richards" sort of moment here. I understand what you're saying, though, and I suspect this guy probably really does believe that gays are generally more effiminite, and other things he asserted. I'm not arguing here, nor have I been, that this guy wasn't using stereotypes. I'm just saying it's pretty hard to take the article seriously (for me, anyway).

Do you really think most of the stereotypes he's using were that serious???

 I don't think he was using them seriously. I labelled them as satire, remember?
 
 However, I have seen people use them seriously. As in, they actually see gay people in that way.
 
 
 
I mean it's not like he was throwing around the promiscuous-thing or the HIV thing or something.

 If your point was that it could have been worse, I acknowledge that.
 But there is no real point in talking about how he could have done something worse.
 I mean, a man could kill an abortion doctor instead of blowing up the abortion clinic at 10:30 a.m., but I don't really think that is any real defense to what ACTUALLY happened.
 
 I am more interested in talking about what he ACTUALLY said...
 
 
 
I've heard white comedians that made a stereotypical remark about blacks and it was fine--blacks laughing too. We aren't talking about a "Michael Richards" sort of moment here.

 I believe I addressed that.
 They are typically making fun of the IDEA of the stereo-type.
 And they typically make that pretty darn clear.
 
 Like in this case, like I said earlier, there is an underlying irony that the author commits by repeatedly claiming he doesn't care to understand gays, while repeatedly making statements that demonstrates he thinks he does by repeating stereo-types. Quite frankly, I think that COULD make a humorous skit if it weren't for the fact that I get the impression that the author IS NOT TRYING to make that ironic point.
 The humor would lie in how people who CLAIM they don't care to understand other people, yet PRETEND that they do understand them through absurd stereo-types, aren't making much sense.
 Since the author never demonstrates an attempt to capitalize on that irony, I would find myself more in a position of laughing "at him" more than "with him". But considering how many people I have encountered who ACTUALLY THINK like this, it has more of a saddening effect than a humorous response from me...
 
 
 
I understand what you're saying, though, and I suspect this guy probably really does believe that gays are generally more effiminite, and other things he asserted. I'm not arguing here, nor have I been, that this guy wasn't using stereotypes. I'm just saying it's pretty hard to take the article seriously (for me, anyway).

 I did call it "satire", did I not?
 I'm just saying that while I didn't take it seriously, I also didn't find any real humor value in it.
 
 You haven't really said if you see any humor value in it regarding the comments on gays.
 Do you?
 
 Perhaps that is a loaded question, but from your statements I don't think you saw any comedy in his article.

What do you find disrespectful about it?
 
 Maybe it is "disrespectful" but I sometimes that's not necessarily so bad. I don't think it rises to the level of being offensive.

 
 Well, think about it. If he was talking about blacks and whites, wouldn't you find it a bit disrespectful?

http://www.chalcedon.edu/articles/0503/050301-3duigon.php

 
 This guy should go to the local mental institution right away!
 
 
 
http://blogs.salon.com/0003494/stories/2004/10/31/gilesDoug.html

 
 Pretty cool but I didn't have time to read most of it.
 
 
 
http://mediamatters.org/items/200604250009

 
 This is why its bad to do drugs.

You haven't really said if you see any humor value in it regarding the comments on gays.
 Do you?
 
 Perhaps that is a loaded question, but from your statements I don't think you saw any comedy in his article.

 
 Not really. It was an interesting article, but not one that I'd describe as "funny".

Not really. It was an interesting article, but not one that I'd describe as "funny".

 
 Would it be wrong if I said it was funny?

Would it be wrong if I said it was funny?

 
 I don't know; I guess it depends on what parts you considered funny. But honestly, I think this article has already received way more analysis here than it really ever deserved.

I don't know; I guess it depends on what parts you considered funny. But honestly, I think this article has already received way more analysis here than it really ever deserved.

 
 I actually agree with a good portion of the article.
Hmm, still no one has responded to #21 and 22. Interesting...

I'm not Homophobic; I'm Chick-O-Centric
 By Doug Giles
 Saturday, February 24, 2007
 
 I think I speak for most heterosexual males when I say I'm not homophobic but chick-o-centric. Let's keep it positive, okay? It's not that we dislike you, the gay guy; it's just that we really like girls. It seems no matter how long we compliantly spend in rehab undergoing the most stringent psychotherapy to rid ourselves of our knee-jerk to your mate choice, the simple fact is . . . heterosexual guys don't "get" gays. Period. 
 
 Heck, we don't understand women. What makes you think we'll ever understand a man who doesn't like women yet wants to be a woman? You just rifled right over our heads. In addition, not only are most men incapable of comprehending what a man sees in another man, we also don't care to try to because football is on-so can we all just shut the hell up with the gay stuff and watch the game?!?

REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni (UNITED STATES) Please, rehab freaks, you're wasting your time on the heterosexual tribe trying to get us to be cool with that which is incomprehensible to us. Just like the homosexual, we are quite happy with our sexual bent and our own little world, so leave us alone, por favor. 
 
 Now, this doesn't mean that heterosexuals hate you, the homosexual. It simply means we're focused on women; which, by command, causes our paths of camaraderie to part. No, this is not a phobia and it doesn't mean we loathe you. It's simply the funk of nature. As a matter of fact, I have several friends that are gay. I kind of view them like dolphins; they're fun, entertaining and creative. I truly enjoy their presence. I just don't know what they get out of eating mullet. My homosexual acquaintances view me in a similar light.

If girls are so icky and men are so mondo-jovial, why do you and a lot of your reps take on feminine mannerisms and dress? I would think that if you are going to be gay you would at least be a man about it. 
 
 It's the same thing with many lesbians. I don't get you. When I hear you speak, it's always "men suck, men are beasts, women rule," yet some of you "ladies" dress and act like men. You wear men's Dockers, men's Polos, you've got a short, man's hair cut, you're looking like Joe Pesci with breasts. You're an ugly version of us. I'm just thinking out loud here. What's-the-dillio? Please explain. It seems as if you would embrace femininity in all its glory like Carrot Top does red hair coloring. Where am I going wrong?

Most Chick-O-Centric males would not raise an unwaxed eye brow at a homosexual man if he would not shove his gayness in our faces. It's the flamers that freak out most heterosexuals. Case in point: Bobby Trendy and Jay Alexander. They seem like nice guys, but the pink hair, lip gloss, heavy eye liner, constant limp wrist and lisp is overkill. Why not, instead of emulating a TBN host, you follow Rob Halford's lead? That would make it much easier for us to have a beer with you. C'mon . . . work with us, we're trying to get along. 
 
 Here are 10 more things you should know about most typical heterosexual males: 
 
 1. Just because we like art and fine furniture, wash our cars, regularly bathe and brush our teeth, and like nice clothes doesn't mean we're latent. What it means is that your team doesn't have a monopoly on taste or decorum. 
 
 2. No, we don't want highlights in our hair or a manicure/pedicure. 
 
 3. We think Vespas are for beautiful girls to ride. Not guys. Harley's, custom West Coast Choppers, Triumphs, Indians or Von Dutchs = a dude's bike. 
 
 4. We don't like dogs that have "toy" as a prefix to their name. 
 
 5. A hunted wild animal's gut pile is a glorious and beautiful thing. Long live the hunt and the hunter. 
 
 6. Keep your lip gloss; we'll use our Carmex. 
 
 7. We like boots not flip flops. 
 
 
 
 "American Idol" host Ryan Seacrest arrives at the 49th Annual Grammy Awards in Los Angeles February 11, 2007. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni (UNITED STATES) 8. Normal men do not like Celine Dion. If you see us crying during one of her shows, it's not because she struck a nerve with a ballad; but rather we are lamenting our manhood slowly draining away from us as we sit here, for the eight time, and listen to this chick whine.

 The above 411 doesn't mean we be hatin'. 
 
 Now, lastly, for those of you heterosexuals that are in competitive sports and don't like to shower with gays, that's cool. It's your right to scrub your butt with whomever you choose. You gay guys should understand our reluctance and not make a big deal over it. I confess, I'm uncomfortable with showering with a homosexual, unless of course it was Portia de Rossi, and I wasn't married. 
 
 To remedy this situation, I propose the following: how about two shower facilities: one for the heterosexuals demarked by a gigantic poster of Beyonce's Sport's Illustrated Swimsuit cover and one for the homosexuals with a big honking 48 x 60" framed print of Ryan Seacrest wearing a chartreuse colored Speedo. [QUOTE=foundit66;252625]I'm not Homophobic; I'm Chick-O-Centric
 By Doug Giles
 Saturday, February 24, 2007
 
 It's the same thing with many lesbians. I don't get you. When I hear you speak, it's always "men suck, men are beasts, women rule," yet some of you "ladies" dress and act like men. You wear men's Dockers, men's Polos, you've got a short, man's hair cut, you're looking like Joe Pesci with breasts. You're an ugly version of us. I'm just thinking out loud here. What's-the-dillio? Please explain. It seems as if you would embrace femininity in all its glory like Carrot Top does red hair coloring. Where am I going wrong? 
 
 
 The reason a lot of lesbians say that hetero men suck is because they usually engage in one or more of the following:
 
 Ask you out on a date and then expect you to give them a blowjob under a city bridge because they want it...
 
 They try and "convert" you while trying to blame their erectile disfunction on you... "oh just keep practicing sweetheart, you'll get it eventually"...
 
 They don't understand any part of the phrase "I'm a lesbian" and keep trying to feel you up against your protests.
 
 They don't know the difference between a labia and a clitoris (and I'm talking men who have been married and actually have children here).
 
 They estrange their daughters because they are lesbians and don't understand why a lesbian wouldn't want to be treated like the above. How clueless can you get?

post_info.post_title: I think you are wrong about lesbians

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Im not Homophobic; Im Chick-O-Centric
